Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <miketout> exactly, but I am working on much cooler capabilities than basic Bancor :)
right now, I have the code setup to enable a full solution to liquidity, high volume, friction free, decentralized exchanging of reserve currencies, also with a solution to front running. Miners and stakers will make blocks that can include conversions to and from a reserve currency. The reserve ratio is determined by a starting point, and then can be modified at every block by things like emission and burn transactions. The reserve ratio is then a function of the starting reserve and net emission. In any single block, all transactions, both buy and sell that can be processed, are, whether or not there are sellers when people want to buy or buyers when people want to sell. Market conversions will always get put into a block and processed as long as they can fit. Limit conversion orders will process if they can be added to the block and still meet the target limit price for conversion.
So, how do we solve front-running and eliminate the possibility of flash trading?
All conversions processed in a single block get exactly the same conversion price for both buys and sells (NO SPREAD!)
There will be a small fee that effectively beats all exchanges but will go only to miners and stakers of the PBaaS reserve chains, which is where the conversions take place, providing even more of a network effect for merge mining and profit opportunities for people who mine and stake chains well beyond block emissions.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> We also expect to make this easy from the wallet across reserve chains, providing full liquidity sharing across the Verus ecosystem, meaning that if any PBaaS fractional reserve currency independently gets on exchanges, it is an option, not a requirement, since full liquidity will be built into the cross-chain protocol.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <Oink> You understand the conversion correct.
Any PBaaS chain will have the Liquid reserve capabilities in addition to all the protocols already implemented in the Komodo ecosystem. So using CC etc, they can interact with any other chain, but not in the sense they interact with Verus, since the protocols Mike described only exist in the Verus Ecosystem.
If this mechanism was implemented in the Komodo ecosystem, basically every chain in the Komodo ecosystem chain could  use it, but for now, it's only the PBaaS chains.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content:
[dscrdvrsc] <miketout> It's kind of like that, but it's also a little more complex. For example, the Bancor equations used for converting from one fractional currency to its reserve, which are simplified forms of our equations look like this:
```
to convert reserve to fractional:
fractionalCurrencyOut = (supply * (pow((reservein / reserve + 1.0), ratio) - 1))
or to convert fractional to reserve:
reserveCurrencyOut = reserve * (pow((fractionalin / supply + 1.0), (1 / ratio)) - 1)```
These equations are solved together for all transactions in a block and all transactions in each block get the same price in either direction. That means that a 1 million Verus reserve could be used in a coin with a 10 million Verus market cap, and if people convert to the coin or use it more than convert from it, it will go up, if it is sold, the price will go down, but all coins, even to the last coin can be sold for Verus through the equations. The depth of the order book is always the entire money supply on the sell side and reserve on the buy side.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> When fractional reserve coins are emitted, the reserve ratio goes down. When they are officially burned, the reserve ratio goes up.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> the closer the reserve ratio is to 1:1, the less volatile the currency can be relative to Verus. the further from it, the more volatile and subject to market forces.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> you will be able to send Verus to reserve chains and to an address on that chain. As part of that send, you will be able to auto convert it to the native PBaaS currency or leave it as Verus tokens on the PBaaS chain and convert it when you want. You will be able to send Verus tokens without gas, because you can pay fees in Verus, which will convert automatically to the native currency. You can also convert any PBaaS reserve currency to Verus with these formulas and send it back to the Verus chain as well.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> at first, we will be able to support Verus as the reserve currency. Eventually, I want to see it go hierarchical in Verus (reserve currencies launching reserves in their ecosystem) and to support external blockchains as well, which would mean Komodo's would be first, since they are our extended ecosystem and closest daemon to us. It will require non-trivial work to be able to do the same for Komodo currencies, but I believe that is possible sooner than any other blockchain system besides Verus. Most of the core concepts are there and the reserve system uses enhaned CCs, which would need to be ported,. The other thing is that all the pieces kind of fit together, and make the whole better with each part. For example, 50% PoS stake and non-equihash proof of power fits right into the model with merge mining support and staking of currency reserves being used to automatically purchase currencies and replenish notarization rewards without external payment. The new merge mining support and PoS security will require either VerusHash 2.0 or similar, or a double-sized block header, since the equihash space is re-purposed. It would be easiest if Komodo also had support for VerusHash 2.0, VerusPoP, but another approach could be just porting the enhanced CCs, adding the consensus changes, then integrating the merkle mountain range to improve/simplify Komodo's notarization and leverage Komodo notarization to create a reserve connector. Basically, there would be a fair bit of work and some consensus rule changes, but it can be done.

Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> thank you for posting the link and getting the discussion going. Nice break from a challenge I'm working on. Right now, I'm trying to determine if there is an algebraic way to solve a very difficult equation, which will allow perfect efficiency with partial fills on limit orders that can be included in a block and by being partially filled, still meet their limit requirements. My default approach is a numerical iteration, which will be able to handle partial fills, but not get a perfect answer to fill them all the way up to the maximum satoshi. The formula to solve is exceedingly complex, so if you know of some exceptional algebraic gurus, please send them my way ;).
